title: Stock Market Fundamentals
description: Learn how stock markets work, how to read stock prices, and understand market mechanics.
objectives: Learn to read stock quotes and market data
Master order types and trading mechanics
Understand market indices and their significance
Learn about market participants and their roles

lessons.title: How Stock Markets Work

content.original: Stock markets are platforms where buyers and sellers trade shares of publicly listed companies. In India, NSE and BSE are primary exchanges. Markets facilitate price discovery through demand-supply dynamics. SEBI regulates all market activities ensuring fair trading practices.
content.simplified: Stock market is like a big shop where people buy and sell company shares. NSE and BSE are India's main stock markets. Prices go up when more people want to buy, and down when more want to sell. SEBI makes sure everyone follows the rules.

lessons.aiSummary: Stock markets = Organized platforms for buying/selling shares. NSE/BSE in India. Price moves based on demand-supply. SEBI = Regulator ensuring fair play.
keyTakeaways: NSE and BSE are India's main stock exchanges
Trading happens electronically, not on physical floor
Market hours: 9:15 AM to 3:30 PM (Mon-Fri)
SEBI protects investor interests

lessons.title: Reading Stock Quotes

content.original: Stock quotes display critical information: Current Price (CMP), Open, High, Low, Previous Close, Volume, Market Cap, P/E Ratio, 52-week High/Low. Green indicates price up, red indicates down. Volume shows liquidity. Market cap determines company size classification.
content.simplified: Stock price screen shows: current price, today's highest and lowest price, yesterday's closing price, how many shares were traded, company's total value, and 52-week range. Green means profit, red means loss.

lessons.aiSummary: Stock quote elements: CMP (current price), Volume (trading activity), 52W H/L (yearly range), Market Cap (company size). Green = gain, Red = loss.
keyTakeaways: CMP = Current Market Price (live price)
Volume indicates how actively stock is traded
52-week high/low shows price range over year
Market cap = Share price √ó Total shares
commonMistakes: Confusing face value with market price
Ignoring volume (low volume = hard to sell)

lessons.title: Order Types and Trading
lessons.videoTopic: Market Orders, Limit Orders, Stop Loss

content.original: Market order executes immediately at current price. Limit order executes only at specified price or better. Stop-loss triggers sale when price falls to set level. Good-till-cancelled (GTC) orders remain active until executed or cancelled. Understanding order types prevents costly mistakes.
content.simplified: Market order: Buy/sell right now at any price. Limit order: Buy/sell only at your decided price. Stop-loss: Automatically sell if price drops below your limit. This protects you from big losses.

lessons.aiSummary: Order types: Market (instant at any price), Limit (only at your price), Stop-loss (auto-sell to limit loss). Use limit orders to control buy/sell price.
keyTakeaways: Market order = Immediate execution, price uncertain
Limit order = Controlled price, execution uncertain
Always use stop-loss for risk management
GTC orders stay active across sessions
commonMistakes: Using market orders for illiquid stocks (price slippage)

lessons.title: Market Indices Explained

content.original: Market indices track overall market performance. Nifty 50 represents top 50 companies on NSE. Sensex tracks 30 companies on BSE. Bank Nifty focuses on banking sector. Indices use free-float market capitalization methodology. They serve as benchmarks for fund performance.
content.simplified: Indices are like report cards for the market. Nifty 50 shows how 50 big companies are doing. Sensex shows 30 big companies. If Nifty goes up, overall market is doing well. Fund managers compare their returns to these indices.

lessons.aiSummary: Indices = Market thermometer. Nifty 50 (NSE's top 50), Sensex (BSE's top 30), Bank Nifty (banking sector). Index up = Market positive. Used as benchmark.
keyTakeaways: Nifty 50 = NSE's benchmark (50 largest companies)
Sensex = BSE's benchmark (30 companies)
Sectoral indices track specific industries
Index funds replicate index performance
commonMistakes: Comparing small-cap stock to Nifty (wrong benchmark)

lessons.title: Market Participants and Roles

content.original: Key participants: Retail investors (individuals), Institutional investors (FIIs, DIIs), Brokers (facilitate trading), Depositories (NSDL, CDSL hold shares electronically), Market makers (provide liquidity), SEBI (regulates). Each plays vital role in market functioning.
content.simplified: Market players: You (retail investor), big companies and foreign investors (institutions), broker (your agent to buy/sell), depository (holds your shares safely like a bank), SEBI (police of stock market). Everyone has a specific job.

lessons.aiSummary: Market participants: Retail investors (you), Institutions (FII/DII), Brokers (trading agents), Depositories (NSDL/CDSL - hold shares), SEBI (regulator). Ecosystem requires all players.
keyTakeaways: Broker connects you to exchange (Zerodha, Groww, etc.)
Demat account holds shares electronically
FIIs bring foreign money, impact market significantly
SEBI monitors and penalizes violations
commonMistakes: Not understanding broker's role (thinking they guarantee profits)
Not checking SEBI registration of advisors
